37:08  "The aging of wine is potentially able to improve the quality of wine. This distinguishes wine from most other consumable goods. While wine is perishable and capable of deteriorating, complex chemical reactions involving a wine's sugars, acids and phenolic compounds (such as tannins) can alter the aroma, color, mouthfeel and taste of the wine in a way that may be more pleasing to the taster. The ability of a wine to age is influenced by many factors including grape variety, vintage, viticultural practices, wine region and winemaking style. The condition that the wine is kept in after bottling can also influence how well a wine ages and may require significant time and financial investment.[1][2] The quality of an aged wine varies significantly bottle-by-bottle, depending on the conditions under which it was stored, and the condition of the bottle and cork, and thus it is said that rather than good old vintages, there are good old bottles. There is a significant mystique around the aging of wine, as its chemistry was not understood for a long time, and old wines are often sold for extraordinary prices. However, the vast majority of wine is not aged, and even wine that is aged is rarely aged for long; it is estimated that 90% of wine is meant to be consumed within a year of production, and 99% of wine within 5 years." (Wikipedia)

3:50 If I recall, the idea of it being approved by God was in tandem with the fact that forces have not stopped you from doing it.  That's why the phrase " God is dead" eventually became a big thing, because it was saying that our culture needed to and was changing, and that your ability to do something was not proof that God was allowing you to do it. As someone who was born in the city the Hudson Bay company abandonded, I loved this video. I always knew about the pig war, but it's good to see all the specifics (like I didn't realize that it was just before the civil war). It was classic local politics almost overriding national concern.   The whole 'straight line' boarder leads to one very bizarre location: Point Roberts, Washington. A tiny pennisula cut off from the rest of the US by Canada. If you want to drive there from the US, you have to enter British Columbia. The boarder crossing at Point Roberts includes handing you a map of the whole pennisula with all the gas stations and the 2 restaurants marked. The major economic driver of Point Roberts is selling cheap gas to Canadians. (So Point Roberts would be really sad if we invaded Canada:).  Side note: I was quite stoked to see that the Hudson Bay Company still exists and is now a major department store.

It's pretty funny to me he calls them "the islands" because there is a bit of a weird naming convention here. That big island he is talking about is indeed called San Jaun Island. However, the collection of disputed islands are also called The San Jaun Islands (dispite each Island having their own proper name). Anyways, Washington State has a pretty robust ferry system that can easily get you and your car out there if you wanna visit to see the main town, the lavender farms, and the two forts established by the British and Americans because of this very conflict. There was a war called the pig war between Serbia and Austo-Hungary from 1909 to 1911. It wasnt an actual war but an economic war in which Austia blocked Serbias live pig trade to the rest of Europe. In the end Serbia won by building factories for meat processing.

33:26
Canadians burned down the white house. Most of the British forces who fought in the War of 1812 were Canadians colonists, former American Revolution troops who fought for their freedom on the side of the British, and so on. But the fact remains. You can use any technicality you want, but America, couldn't take Canada by force, end of story. You call it a draw? No, it wasn't a draw, if it were a draw, the Americans would have had more say in the negotiations. But instead, they basically had to do everything the Canadians wanted, including, but not limited to, paying to build Dalhousie University in Halifax, Nova Scotia. The losing side had to pay out in order to avoid a full scale invasion as a response to their attempted annexation of Canada. Of course you call it 'The Pig War'. Americans never cease to amaze me with their undeserved arrogance.

San Juan Island National Historical Park is to this day under the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) category V protected landscape, made up of the sites of the British and U.S. Army camps during the Pig War. So this is serious, not a laughing matter!

Commanding on San juan island and fighting for the confederate army at the same time! And hunt there also going awol staying on the island and starting a family on the island that presists to this day.   So since OS couldn't be bothered to give simple and accurate info here is a quick simple run down.  Pig is shot Farmer threatened with arrest American settlers petion local army General sends Pickett  Brits send 2 ships Pickett moves camps -back and forth a few times he was an idiot- Royal marines land on otherside of island and set camp. Orders come from both sides not to escalate Pickett goes awol to join confederates in the Civil war. Hunt is new commander for americans Tensions ease parties ensue Civil war ends The kaiser agreement happened  The san juans are American all of Vancouver is Canadian. Royal marines leave American take control of british camp Hunt stays CO of troops until they are recalled. -started a family on the island descendants are still thereâ€  A few notes: Yes the southern tip of Vancouver was also being contested as American. they really liked that line.  The first settlers were American and not Hawaiian that family is still there too. The tax offical came to see them and found the british were there during the same trip.  The sheep plays out mostly right accept there were no native raiders and the sheep's were auctioned to the American family. It's funny how, as someone who was born in Victoria and went through public school in south Vancouver Island, this is the most I learned about this struggle EVEN THOUGH my early highschool Social Studies/History classes were supposed to teach us students about this.   You can see the San Juan Islands from the east coast of Victoria...they're about 20 kms away. This history happened very close by, and yet all I remember from school was essentially: 'The British made Fort Victoria the capital of British Columbia so that the Americans wouldn't take the island during the Gold Rush.' Very mis-represented and over simplified.   But leave it to Oversimplified to make an informative and fun take on history that has been neglected by school curriculum. This video is filled with so much cringeworthy vitriol towards America and Americans.
Something about Oversimplified's descent into madness gets me everytime.
TLDR: We ought to be a bit more humble and look for the ways we are inconsistent in our own actions, instead of just doing the lazy attack on bad people in the past.  You know, the most common thing people say when looking at history (especially western history in the last 500 years), the easiest and laziest thing to do is point at those people and say "How didn't they realize how bigoted and hypocritical they were? It's so clear to us, here and now, so far removed from the culture and context they lived in." It's almost like we think they existed in a society that had the same ideas about human & civil rights that we do, and they just chose to ignore it out of selfishness, greed, and good old-fashioned pure EVILâ„¢. There were definitely elements of that, but for the most part the aggressive racist hypocrisy of the past was economically, culturally, and legally reinforced in social consciousness. With the exception of VERY few people, they didn't take a hard look at themselves to consider whether these actions were inconsistent with their own morals.  And why would they? WE, TODAY, DON'T DO THIS EITHER. Sure, we point out moral problems in larger society, but we don't search for a possible cause in ourselves. No, we blame and attack other people. Everyone from every political affiliation at every point in history does this, and we should not fool ourselves into believing that we have improved that much. Maybe some God damn humility and introspection would do us some good.  ***In case it must be said, this is NOT to justify acts of cruelty, bigotry, and oppressionâ€”past or present. My only point is to demonstrate that we should be more aware of how easy it is to fall into the same cognitive dissonance that tyrants and oppressors use to justify themselves.***

Day 13 of me rewatching The Pig War - Oversimplified until he returns with another video
There should be an Oversimplified about the Civil Rights Movement, what it took to get there, what were the roadblocks in the way of desegregation, and the ideas and examples we use today for racial rights. I know this could span hundreds of years from the founding of the Colonies to the Lyndon Johnson Presidency... but it could bring awareness of that is HOW LONG IT TOOK FOR DAMN LEGISLATION TO SET UP EQUAL RIGHTS! Yes, we ended slavery in the Civil War, we gave African Americans the ballot in The Reconstruction (spoiler, not really),  but we only bothered to listen to plight to gain African American workers and soldiers during World War F**king Two! The time we ever give all African Americans the ballot for real is with the Voting Rights Act of 1965, a year after the Civil Rights Bill of 1964! Even the World was making fun of the USA by nation politicians mocking US delegation with civil rights questions when they try diplomacy to non-white countries like India and Africa.  All I'm trying to say, is that we came an embarrassingly long way to finally give equality a chance, and it is still a fight to this day. I think going over The Civil Rights Movement will be not only informative, but also entertaining of how this country fumbles of how the legislation constitutes 'freedom' with 'all men'.

Can we have a moment of silence for John Jacob Astor for being lost to history. He was a German immigrant who became the first multi millionaire in the US and in 1810 funded an overland expedition to the Oregon territory. He founded Fort Astoria in 1811, which was a fur trading post. But due to the breakout of The War of 1812 sold it to Hudson Bay in so it wouldn't be targeted by the British.

OverSimplified in 2030: Ukraine-Russia War - OverSimplified
11:45 An Englishman sends an Irishman to take Hawaiian Polynesian people to colonize an island named after Saint John, but in Spanish, that shared its name with an existing Spanish colony in the Caribbean.   Mister Worldwide
Borders based on rivers are an incredibly dangerous decision. One that led to constant warring in future.  Rivers have this tendency to erode soil and change their position. River meandering.  Of course, without satellites in orbit, determining borders was much harder. So it was perfectly understandable that some surveyors might not notice a river has move and claim their neighbors had invaded their territory.   I think this is why the US decided to make most of the states claimed from the Mexico very square. Lines of longitude and latitude may have been easier to calculate. Because it's not like there's many rivers out in the desert.

2:36 Only US propaganda can claim that the war of 1812 was anything but a British victory. US tried to invade Canada and was repelled. That's a qualified British victory.  My country (Serbia) attacked the Ottoman Empire in 1876. trying to liberate some of the majority Serbian-inhabited land it occupied (south of today's Serbia) and was repelled and lost some ground in the Ottoman counterattack (even though we won some battles). And even though the borders did not change in the peace terms nobody here is trying to claim it as a draw. Similar thing happened in 1885. war with Bulgaria. Greece was likewise repelled in 1897 and 1922 by the Ottomans and didn't lose any of its prewar ground. Still a defeat is a defeat.

Just to FYI the ad in the middle.  VPN's don't do as much for security as basically every VPN ad ever claims.  They make it harder for someone to target you specifically in various ways, but they don't do much of anything for security attacks that are not targeting you specifically (which is most of them).

You could do a short video on the "Honey War" between Missouri and Iowa. Its very similar to this, a sheriff comes in to collect taxes and is told to get off the property, steals some honeycombs and is thrown in prison. Military shows up on one side, a bunch of farmers with farming gear converted into weapons show up on the other, it looks like something is going to go down, but finally cooler heads prevail and nothing happens. Oddly enough though, the border between Missouri and Iowa is still being disputed to this day. There's an "agreement", but that's it.

This IS pretty oversimplified, more than usual lol. The Americans had a vested interest in access to the Puget Sound, not just the Columbia. the Columbia, for starters, was difficult and dangerous to navigate, due to the sand bars at its mouth, so the puget sound with its calm, deep waters, became immensely desirable to both parties. In the original territory negotiations, the British refused to allow american ownership of any territory around the sound, so both just settled on joint occupation.  also, the fur trade was already on its way out due to over poaching. The Hudson Bay Company, by the time of Douglas, was already diversifying its economic interests into logging, farming, and mining due to the dwindling beaver supply, and lack of demand in Europe due to shifting interests.

Time stamps for this video were: - 00:23 Introduction to The Pig War - 00:56 Treaty of Paris, 1783 - 01:18 "Quit ogling our territory!" - 01:27 Canadian colonies attempted to be part of the United States - 02:28 War of 1812 - 03:19 Oregon Country - 04:16 Manifest Destiny - 05:22 Joint Occupation of Oregon - 05:52 "Well then you, my friend, should use NordVPN!" - 06:58 "...and a Joint Occupation of Oregon." - 07:05 James Douglas - 07:25 Fort Vancouver infested - 07:54 Relocation to Fort Victoria - 08:10 "54-40 or FIGHT!" - 08:28 British alarmed by news of Joint Occupation Agreement - 09:06 The Oregon Treaty (1846) - 10:23 "Order! Order! Shut up!" - 11:15 Governor of Vancouver Island - 11:51 Set up a sheep farm in San Juan Island - 12:31 American customs collector sails on the island - 13:31 Collect taxes on British property - 13:53 "You're a magistrate now." - 14:17 Whatcom County - 15:22 "San Juan Sheep Raid!!" in the news - 16:28 Fort Victoria infested - 17:39 Chasing a pig out of a property - 19:38 Confronting a pig killer - 20:15 In charge of the department of Oregon - 21:25 Scheme mode - 23:21 American troops entered the island - 23:45 British official sent to an island - 24:21 Respond to American provocation with force - 25:11 More American troops on an island - 26:08 Move American camp to another location - 26:37 Sheep pasture trampled by soldiers and tourists alike - 26:54 Joint Military Occupation - 27:52 Governor Douglas outranked by Rear Admiral Baynes - 28:30 Word made it across the planet - 29:54 General Winfield Scott - 31:15 "So, you see, General..." - 32:03 "He made me do it" - 33:36 Pickett back on an island - 34:13 War is avoided - 34:34 Civil War (1861 - 1865) - 34:49 Pickett become a Confederate General - 35:12 Trent Affair - 35:33 San Juan Boundary issue on list, 12 years later - 36:06 San Juan island awarded to United States of America - 36:37 In conclusion to The Pig War

Yes... early Americans were expansionist...like basically every group of human beings before them! Shocking... I know. Hard for millennials and generation Twitter/Facebook to understand. Especially if they went to public schools (Especially in liberal cities and teacher union controlled schools).  For example, the Lakota Soiux tribe started out hundreds of years ago in the area of the Ohio River Valley. Over decades, the migrated up over the great lakes and down into the plains..SLAUGHTERING every other tribe they encountered. Killing, pillaging and even taking salves. Then, the Soiux and Pawnee battled and killed each other for decades BEFORE the evil white man got there. They just did it in small numbers unlike the Europeans who seem to only be happy when armies of thousands slaughter each other. Then again, the natives hadn't figured out the wheel....yet!  So, just one example of countless many. Humans are territorial and will fight and kill for resources. Hell, even our closest biological cousins, the great apes, do the same. Chimpanzees are brutal little bastards. The don't just kill their enemies...they freaking EAT THEM as well! Kinda like the Japanese...lol.  Nations NOT expanding and colonizing is a relatively new phenomenon. Well, apparently Russia/Putin hasn't caught on yet but...yea. So... when smack talking early Americans.... remember... yea... wasn't cool what they did but they weren't unique in doing it. Besides... do we really want to have say... Spanish neighbors in the south west or French to the north? Those people.... kinda crazy cultures...lol.

bet you won't make a video about Alexander the Great.  I bet it's pretty simple to break down Alexander... He was born to a Macedonian King and to a Greek Noblewoman With the king and queens marriage, Macedonia founded a League of Corinth or the Hellenic League founded by Philip II. Philip II gets assassinated after Alexander returns after fighting the Thebes and the Athenians enslaving them for the cause.  The king and future King had a bitter argument before Alexander's return from war about succession and leadership and what not.  Note: Philip II was assassinated during the Olympic Games, so it would be pretty cool to see a video about Alexander given the fact the Winter Olympic Games has commenced.   Alexander's empire went from Greece, in the lands of modern day Iraq and Iran, well past Afghanistan, and into the African plains of Egypt, the Empire continues into Bactria and into the Indus River. His Empire, even went to the gates of Persia and made their way through into unknown Indian territories. Alexander put down revolts, and mutiny's at this time. Even hunting down a commander named Bessus 'the Usurper'  that betrayed Dorias III of Persia well into the lands of the Hindu Kush and unknown areas in the Caucasus.  While doing this he established cities and named them Alexandria after himself. He established several cities all which were burned down in a civil war after the Great King passed away. All but one remained, the one he founded in Egypt his very first Alexandria, whom people say it is his resting place underneath a crypt within a Greek Orthodox Church.   Because of Alexander's empire shattering, Rome conquered the lands afterwards, asserting dominance over Greece. And through Julius Augustus Caesar, he conquered the former African territories, his inspired hero once did.  Alexander's noble titles: Basileus of Macedon Hegemon (Head/Sovereign) of the Hellenic League Strategos Autokrator (Commander-in-chief) of Greece Shahanshah (Shah) of Persia Pharaoh of Egypt Lord of Asia

My grandparents lived on San Juan Island, so every summer we'd visit on vacation. My grandma was obsessed with The Pig War, so much so that she built a building and created a Pig War Museum. She had old mannequins and wax figures dressed up as the primary people. When we'd visit she have us dress up as some of the characters. We have a picture of my younger sister dressed up as the pig and my dad as Lyman. I always thought she was crazy. At the time I only knew the pig shooting parts of story. She never went into the insane amount of politics that surrounded the incident. Thanks for helping me revisit my childhood.

Ever heard of the War of Jenkins' Ear? It lasted for nine years in the mid-eighteenth century between Britain and Spain and was supposedly started because the Spanish coastguard cut off the 'ear' of a captain of a British merchant ship while searching it for contraband in the Caribbean. To prove it, Captain Jenkins produced his pickled 'ear' in the British parliament. I use inverted commas around the word ear because the story goes that the Spanish did not cut off Captain Jenkins ear at all, but a rather more intimate part of his body, which may well be the case, because he wouldn't need to pickle his ear to prove he didn't have it. However if, for instance, the part/s that had been sliced off would normally be found in Captain Jenkins underwear, keeping it/them in a pickle jar would undoubtedly be marginally more acceptable for  proof and display purposes than the only alternative, don't you think?... and describing it/them as an 'ear' might also be marginally more acceptable at the time, although I have to admit that personally I would love it if it had actually been called  The War of Jenkins' Bollocks.

2:39 As an American living in Canada, I got teased a lot for the war. I couldnâ€™t accept the fact that the Americans lost to Canadians outside of the hockey rink (I love Canada, donâ€™t get me wrong), so I did some research. The war is taught differently in schools in Canada, America, and Britain. Canada teaches that they won the war. America teaches that they won the war. Britain teaches that it was a part of the Napoleonic War, and thus they won it. All are wrong, and yet right. Canadians did achieve their primary goal: survive. But they didnâ€™t win in a 1v1; Britain viewed the war at the time as a way to prevent Americans from getting cozy with Napoleon (the USA wasnâ€™t yet a superpower, but the potential was visible even then); and though the US didnâ€™t conquer Canada, they did achieve their primary goal: make Britain stop harassing their overseas trade routes.

World War I (WWI) was a global war centered in Europe that began on July 28, 1914 until November 11, 1918. This war is often called the World War or the Great War from occurring until the start of World War II in 1939, and the First World War or World War I after that. This war involved all of the world's great powers,[5] which was divided into two opposing alliances, namely the Allies (based on the Triple Entente consisting of Great Britain, France, and Russia) and the Central Powers (centered on the Triple Alliance consisting of Germany, Austria- Hungary, and Italy; however, when Austria-Hungary went on the offensive while the alliance was on the defensive, Italy did not join the war). [6] The two alliances reorganized (Italy was on the side of the Allies) and expanded as many countries took part. war. More than 70 million military soldiers, including 60 million Europeans, were mobilized in one of the largest wars in history. [7][8] More than 9 million soldiers died, mainly as a result of technological advances that increased the lethality of a weapon without considering improved protection or mobility. World War 1 (PDI) was a global war centered in Europe that started on July 28, 1914 until November 11, 1918. This war is often called the World War or the Great War since it occurred until the start of World War II in 1939, and the First World War or World War I after that. This war involves World War I after that. This war involved all of the world's great powers,[5] which was divided into two opposing alliances, namely the Allies (based on the Triple Entente consisting of Great Britain, France, and Russia) and the Central Powers (centered on the Triple Alliance consisting of Germany, Austria- Hungary, and Italy; however, when Austria-Hungary went on the offensive while the alliance was on the defensive, Italy did not join the war). [6] The two alliances reorganized (Italy was on the side of the Allies) and expanded as many countries entered the war. More than 70 million military soldiers, including 60 million Europeans, were mobilized in one of the largest wars in history. [7] [8] More than 9 million soldiers died, mainly as a result of technological advances that increased the lethality of a weapon without considering improved protection or mobility. World War I (WWI) was a global war centered in Europe that began on July 28, 1914 until November 11, 1918. This war is often called the World War or the Great War from occurring until the start of World War II in 1939, and the First World War or World War I after that. [6] The two alliances reorganized (Italy was on the side of the Allies) and expanded as many countries took part. war. [6] The two alliances reorganized (Italy was on the side of the Allies) and expanded as many countries entered the war. More than 70 million military soldiers, including 60 million Europeans, were mobilized in one of the largest wars in history. [7] [8] More than 9 million soldiers died, mainly as a result of technological advances that increased the lethality of a weapon without considering improved protection or mobility. World War II or the Second World War, often  abbreviated as WWII or WW2, was a global war that lasted from 1939 to 1945. It involved the vast majority of the world's countries-including all of the great powers-forming two opposing military alliances: the Allies and the Axis powers. In a total war directly involving more than 100 million personnel from more than 30 countries, the major participants threw their entire economic, industrial, and scientific capabilities behind the war effort, blurring the distinction between civilian and military resources. Aircraft played a major role in the conflict, enabling the strategic bombing of population centres and the only two uses of nuclear weapons in war. World War II was by far the deadliest conflict in human history; it resulted in 70 to 85 million fatalities, a majority being civilians. Tens of millions of people died due to genocides (including the Holocaust), starvation, massacres, and disease. In the wake of the Axis defeat, Germany and Japan were occupied, and war crimes tribunals were conducted against German and Japanese leaders.

33:26
The interesting "What if?" scenarios certainly involves the Civil War. If the Pig War did happen, would the Civil War be delayed as the southern states would remain in the Union, at least until the end of the Pig War? Or would the Civil War happen sooner, with the southern states seceding and plunging the Union into conflicts from all sides? Also, the southern states could publicly support and participate in the Pig War, but privately wrangle major concessions from the federal government (lest they do decide to secede in the middle of fighting), resulting in a much weaker central federal government. Might be a nice setup for alternate history debate and discussion.

Thinking about Harney and Pickett's subsequent careers, I think Harney was motivated more by some hotheaded patriotism than anything else. He had a few opportunities to defect to the confederacy but did not so although he was no abolitionist - he was also no traitor. Pickett was a traitor but also a capable enough combat General who never forgave Lee for the charge that bears his name where the world got a preview of WWI (the high water mark of the confederacy was an anomaly in what was otherwise a straight up WWI like massacre of Pickett's division).

A curly tale, well told. When the trivial and the consequential wrestle, hilarity is sure to ensue.  Manifest Destiny was indeed intended to apply to the whole continent. Whether by force of arms or weight of gold, the monarchies were to be cleared out. But the civil war put that on hold and the threat of the Union Army eventually "liberating" the colonies of British North America, precipitated the birth of Canada in 1867. James Douglas kept the grubby Yanks at bay until 1871 when British Columbia joined the Maple Syrup Mafia.

Here is the Complete Jewish Bible translation of Isaiah 42:11-12  LetÂ the desert and its citiesÂ raise their voices, the villages whereÂ KedarÂ lives; let those living inÂ SelaÂ shout for joy; let them cry out fromÂ the mountaintops! Isaiah 42:20  You have seen many things, but you pay no attention; your ears are open, but you do not listen.  The book of Deuteronomy did so as well.  I will raise up for them a prophet like you from among their brothers.Â And I will put my words in his mouth, andÂ he shall speak to them all that I command him. [Deuteronomy 18:18] This is God speaking to Moses. The Jews said that the Prophet will be from the children of Israel, but when you read further, â€œNo prophet ever rose again in Israel like Moses, whom the Lord knew with such great intimacyâ€ [Deuteronomy 34:10]" The Prophet could not have been from the children of Israel. He must have been a gentile. Because otherwise, this would be a clear contradiction in the book of Deuteronomy. It can only be removed when assuming that the said Prophet was a gentile.  The 'whom i uphold' part is actually said to be intentionally falsified. The original hebrew word used there was the name Ahmad, which basically has the same meaning as Muhammad. But if you change it just a little bit, you get 'whom i uphold'.  some as the southmost part of the Desert of Paran (which scholars linked or identified with the Sinai Desert) or the entire desert, and others said that it is a collective name of a mountain range between the Zin Desert and the Sinai Desert.  I will raise up for them a prophet like you from among their brothers. And I will put my words in his mouth, and he shall speak to them all that I command him. [Deuteronomy 18:18] There are some important details provided in this short prophecy. We are told that this future Prophet will be similar to Moses (â€œa prophet like youâ€). We are also told that he will be a mouthpiece for God as he will faithfully relay all of Godâ€™s commands (â€œhe shall speak to them all that I command himâ€). This verse also reveals the people from which the Prophet will   arise, â€œfrom among their brothersâ€. An important question we must consider is which people does â€œbrothersâ€ refer to here? The prophet was a gentile. And the Prophet referred to here is Muhammad(Saw). Itâ€™s important to note that biblical geographers differ as to the exact location of Paran. However, they are unanimous that Paran is somewhere within Arabia. From Clarkeâ€™s Commentary on the Bible: He dwelt in the wilderness of Paran â€“ This is generally allowed to have been a part of the desert belonging to Arabia Petraea, in the vicinity of Mount Sinai; and this seems to be its uniform meaning in the sacred writings. Strongâ€™s Bible Dictionary also tells us that Paran is a desert of Arabia: H6290 paÌ‚â€™raÌ‚n From H6286; ornamental; Paran, a desert of Arabia: â€“ Paran. Sebeos, a seventh century Armenian bishop and historian, when describing the Arab conquest of his time, wrote that the Arabs â€œassembled and came out from Paranâ€ [5]. Encyclopaedia Biblica, edited by Reverend T. K. Cheyne, asserts: â€œParan refers to the Arab tribal names, farran or faran.â€ The Bible tells us that Paran is the very place where Ishmael dwelt: â€œWhile he (Ishmael) was living in the Desert of Paran, his mother got a wife for him from Egyptâ€ [Genesis 21:21]   The dwelling place of Ishmael was none other than Arabia. The Dead Sea Scrolls, which are dated to the second century BCE and represent the oldest surviving manuscript evidence for the Old Testament along with other apocryphal books, link Ishmael, his descendants and Paran to Arabia: "And Ishmael and his sons, and the sons of Keturah and their sons, went together and dwelt from Paran to the entering in of Babylon in all the land which is towards the East facing the desert. And these mingled with each other, and their name was called Arabs, and Ishmaelite." Hence, the Paran (or Pharan) of Ishmael was certainly in the Arabian Peninsula. In fact, we can narrow this location down further. Modern academic research supports the claim that Ishmaelâ€™s Paran was indeed in a specific part of Arabia known as Hijaz, modern-day Western Saudi Arabia. Irfan Shahid, one of the worldâ€™s most renowned authorities on pre-Islamic, ancient Arabian geography/history, stated that there was a place called Pharan in Hijaz, which belonged to the Sulaym tribe . Professor Haseeb   Shehada, an Israeli scholar and professor, in his translation of the Samaritan version of the Torah suggested an identification of the wilderness of Paran with the desert of Western Arabia which is known today as Hijaz  and when the Jews went to the Christ and asked for a sign he said children of men there shall be no sign except Jonah sign which is living three times when he was supposed to die each  in the sea a whale sallowed him   In the whale belly he was spat into the island  On the Island a pumpkin grew on him  So Jesus was  seen eating fish and honeycomb after his crossing by the disciples   seen walking after being buried and a rock was put on his grave by a women  and a third which he will comeback on    "The scepter shall not depart from Judah, nor a lawgiver from between his feet,Â untilÂ Shiloh comes, and unto him shall the gathering of the people be." Not Brain Death or Cardiac Death, But Killing Professor Li Huige, professor of pharmacology from University Medical Centre Mainz in Germany, described four types of organ harvesting in China based on witnessesâ€™ testimonies and publications. The first two types concern prisoners sentenced to death, and last two types involve prisoners of conscience and political prisoners. Although the term brain death was often cited by Chinese doctors as having occurred prior to the harvesting of organs, numerous publications from Chinese medical professionals showed otherwise. Professor Li said that â€œ[it is] neither brain death nor cardiac death. It was a living patient who was killed by the doctors by removing the heart.â€  Professor Li cited one paper from Henan Medical Research that described heart transplantations performed at the Chinese People's Armed Police Forces Hospital in 2001. He pointed out that at that time, there was no concept of brain-death or related legislation yet. For heart removal, systemic heparinization was performed. But systemic heparinization can work only when the heart and the circulation is working. â€œSo, the person is also not a cardiac dead patient, either,â€ he said.  â€œDetailed description showed cold cardioplegia solution was delivered to the heart through the aortic root until the heart stopped beating. This means the heart was beating and a cold cardioplegia solution caused cardiac arrest,â€ Li explained, â€œSo this person, this so-called donor, was not a brain dead patient, was not a cardiac patient, was a living person who was killed by medical professionals. This very likely is a situation of organ harvesting from prisoners of conscience.â€  David Beyda, Chair and Professor for the Department of Bioethics and Medical Humanism at the University of Arizona, said people were put in prison as goods to supply organs, instead of being treated as human beings. In other words, the surgeons that conducted transplants were actually killing them.

Edit:  0:31-0:51 As if white people didn't set the precedence of conquering each other throughout their history, pretending Britian and France and the Norsemen didn't colonize and expand their own territories. You even mock Henry VIII about needing to conquer a bit of France in his own video fam! Or the conflicts between the Scots and Welsh and Irish down to the Anglos and Saxxons... How about the various Italian city-states, or even Rome and it's broad imperial history and the previous Greek history of expansion.   As if every other color/race hasn't done the same among their own peoples and regions and kingdoms. I'll raise you an entire Chinese history, Babylonian/Assyrian/Zoroastrian history, the Korean peninsula's history, Mayan, Aztec, know what, everywhere. Point to a place on a map and there's been human civilization expansion and power grabs.   As if every other border hasn't faced some kind of racial tension. Like Egypt and the Levant hasn't gone through various phases of rulers. Pretending Spain doesn't have Arabic influence and a huge chunk of Islamic history, like the Moors don't exist and never conquered the Iberian peninsula in white man's Europe. Pretending Mansa Musa didn't conquer through both trade and war to become the richest man ever, and he was black selling black men and women as slaves. Pretending the Silk Road didn't have racial blending and authoritarian regimes controlling sections and conflicits. Pretending the Mongols didn't spread their DNA everywhere they went.   All I'm saying is if you're going to make extremely racist jokes like this, calling out one color and insinuating that was the entire moral crux of a position, it's important to point out that (for what it's worth) that was merely what's been done in every human history. In every government. In every regime. Be it Idi Amin or the Mean Moustache Man we can't Voldemort by YouTube or Stalin or Vlad the Impaler or Noda Obunaga or Shaka Zulu. By this standard, the US Westward Expansion was done by treating the Indigenous Americans as equals, through war and deception as has always been done. Was it fair or just or morally right? *NO. NO IT WAS NOT.* But it wasn't anything new. So, I used to actually live on the street next to American camp on San Juan island, as in three or four houses down was the entrance. I used to walk my dog there every morning and walk through the actual camp, past the cabins that are still there, and up to the battery where the canons were. When you say that the camp is exposed, its true, there is absolutely nothing out there but open field between camp and the water. I was actually just out at American camp with my children a few months ago. English camp is also still on the island and is one of the few places where the US government will hoist the flag of another country without diplomatic status (according to wikipedia).

This man had way too much fun doing the ending of this vid
So, firstly, you got the ENTIRE settlement phase just... wrong. The native tribes weren't noble savages living in perfect harmony with nature, but a thousand different bands of highly aggressive, independent warrior-societies that raided, attacked, enslaved, and massacred each other, just as much as they did whites that encroached on their lands. Look into the Commanche - their name literally means "the enemy" or "rapist" in the language of their rival tribes for VERY good reasons.  Adding on to that, there was no single great unified surge west. Rather, it was a process that occurred over a huge amount of time, often in spurts and trickles, and was more like the ebb of the flow of the tide than some grand, racially motivated occupation.  On top of that - the one thing you got right was that, yes, it did take American settlers to develop the western territories. The French had only minimally developed some parts of their holdings, largely along the Mississippi river, and there were no urban centers north of mexico and west of the river by that time. The Mississippi cheifdoms were long since destroyed, largely by flu and tuberculosis, and hadn't even really come into contact with Europeans and ends in the mid-late 16th century.  Generally speaking, not only was this a gross misrepresentation of the time period, but also incredibly racist and just plain wrong.

Funny stuff. Douglas looking a bit white for a man who wasn't considered so by the Americans (his mother was a Creole, so single drop theory probably made him count as black in most American eyes despite passing fairly easily as white, and he married a Metis woman), but the funny thing is he did indeed not like Americans. In fact, he didn't like them so much he made sure American ships were greeted by a black militia whenever their passengers got off the boat. Also, he was allegedly involved in a man being beaten to death with a shovel. The racial angle might have been involved in the dispute too, now that I think about it, at least if a hotheaded Slave owning Southerner was involved.  Also, while Wilhelm was indeed related to Queen Vickie, Germany was also in a bit of a rivalry with Britain, so agreeing to let the Germans arbitrate was basically incredibly one-sidedly unintelligent.

I don't really have much to add, except to say that you outdid yourself this time. Your content is brilliant.  American British relations during the American Civil war would actually make a really nice topic for a Mini Episode. It was very murky, and fairly interesting. A lot of the upper class empathized with the plantation class in the south, but much of the working class in England actually supported the Union during the Civil War especially in Hull, the home of William Wilberforce, whose widely regarded as the father of the Abolitionist movement in England, and in Manchester where there is Statue of Lincoln over the City's reaction to the Embargo (Which in itself is a fascinating story: The cotton mills in Manchester were once said to have "clothed the world" but over half of them were idle during the war as a result of the blockade. But a vote taken by workers in the Manchester Free Trade Hall in 1862, agreed to risk starvation and destitution, and maintain support for Lincoln and the embargo.)  Also, insofar as the Alabama claims are concerned, the British Government were apparently unaware of the ship even being built until it had been launched, and even though the PM at the time (Lord Palmerston) was thought to sympathize with the Confederacy, Parliament as a whole were *furious*, detaining other ships destined for the Confederacy. Which is a hilarious image.  If theres one topic I'd like to a mini episode on, its on the Anglo-Portuguese Alliance: The Oldest Military Alliance in History.

You should do a video about the West Virginia Coal Wars of 1921. The labor tensions became so high that workers ambushed company coal convoys in hit-and-run battles, and during the Battle of Blair mountain fighting between the police and the labor unions became so intense that the US army had to intervene. The coal mine companies even had private airplanes drop makeshift bombs on the fighting workers! It became national news and eventually paved the way for future labor reforms and workers rights legislation.

This is a very good video! It is, however, unfortunate to see Oversimplified endorse the critical race perspective of history, which is the idea that the primary motivating factor of American aggression towards native Americans was primarily a factor related to race. Although there was a lot of racism that went into justifying the position of Americans at the time, imperial tendencies would have driven Americans to attack and kill anyone who was between them and the goals of Manifest Destiny. This video clearly shows white people attacking white people for the primary motivators behind almost all of history: money and power. Perhaps fittingly to the name, Oversimplifiedâ€™s endorsement of the critical race perspective actually is a massive oversimplification that turns history from the complex study of human interaction, nations and civilizations to a crude, elementary level perspective of â€œwhite man bad.â€ White man was bad to Native Americans, but racism is hardly a primary motivating factor and rather a convenient secondary excuse for expanding the American influence and economy.

To be fair, the destruction of Washington was in retaliation for an earlier US attack on the Parliament of Lower Canada at York (now Toronto). The US also looted, taking a royal standard, the first Mace of Ontario, a golden staff used by Upper Canada's Parliament, and a lion statuette, carved out of wood and painted gold.  So, told them to pound sand. Today, the standard and lion are just two of the hundreds of "trophies of war" on display at the US Naval Academy in Annapolis, Maryland.

My biggest gripe is that these new videos just have jokes that just fall flat, they feel forced. I still absolutely love this channel and want to see it grow even more, but I don't want these videos to become annoying to watch because of the over saturation of jokes. Describing the American spread West as like rats or a disease is not exactly the smartest or fairest of things to say, given that almost everyone who did the spreading were poor working class or agricultural families just trying to make a living on new farmland while most of the atrocities were committed by government troops who came a bit later to claim enforce their rule. Its also not a very smart metaphor because its exactly the same metaphor that is being used to describe the spread of people today, commonly known as immigrants.  Protraying the majority of families in hardship seeking a new life of oppurtunity out west (much like immigrants today) in the same light as brutal government troops and the minority of settlers hell bent on racist genocide is unfair and inappropriate.

THE KING HAS RETURNED
As a Master's of History Student applying for his PhD whose hometown is Victoria BC, I salute you.   Fun facts bout British Columbia during this time period:  1. There were several gold rushes aside from the Fraser Canyon on in 1858. The Queen Charlotte's Gold Rush (1851) the Simikameen (1859) Rock Creek (1859) Stikine (1861), Omineca (1861), Cariboo (1862), Goldstream (1863), Leechtown (1864), Wild Horse Creek (1864), Big Bend (1865), Sooke (1865), and several others in this time period. James Douglas as well as the Russian Alaskan Governor made efforts to suppress news of the rushes.   2. These Gold miners (who were largely failed miners from the 1848/1849 California Gold Rush, and not JUST settlers from the Oregon Trail) were purported to be very aggressive toward the Native peoples and constantly tested British authority in the regions they were in (i.e. Fraser Canyon War). One time a judge had his hat shot off by an american miner's revolver, but he didnt flinch, walked up to him, and took his gun away from him.   3. The population in Fort Victoria swelled from just a few hundred to 20,000 within 2 months! This population shift essentially made many facets of life on the Canadian West Coast culturally American in everything. The China Town, San Fransisco-esque architecture and many other made it american in everything but name. (Ironically, it was the end of the gold rush that ended a possible American take over of the region, though this is speculation).   4. There was a very real chance of invasion by the USA during the Civil War (USA Politics were reflected often Victoria, with some shops and bars actively flying the Confederate flag in support, and one conspiracy for some Confederate sympathizers to steal some ships and raid coastal California).  5. African Americans found Vancouver Island very attractive and so many came up north from California as well to escape slavery (see his video on Civil War for the details on the politics). There is a legend that Isaac Mull, a freed slave, began singing gospel songs and one of the places near Sooke is named "The Happy Valley" because of it. There was also a sizeable contingent who would fight for the British should war begin between the USA and Great Britain, "The Black Pioneer Regiment". The Stark family, one of the oldest pioneer families on Saltspring Island, were african americans.   6. The "Fur Trade being interrupted" was true to a certain degree, but it was also so that the HBC could maintain peaceful relations with the indigenous peoples. Reflective of this, the lingua franca of the west coast wasnt English, but Chinook Wawa (words like Skookum are an example of this effect). Unfortunately, there was a sizable Smallpox Epidemic in 1862 that swept along the west coast and killed off many smaller or more vulnerable groups. The modern day Lekwungen / Songhees nation of Esquimalt were able to survive partly because they were evacuated to Discovery Island (you cant go there now as it's closed to the public. I went for a service project about 2013 and was even stalked at night by the famous wolf, Takaya).   7. The Gold Miners were so desperate for transport they imported Bactrian Camels from the Mongolian Desert. Dead Ass Serious, and it's incredible.   8. Douglas was nervous bout the Americans as his own hold over the native bands was tenuous at best, and hollow at worst. Fort Victoria was besieged in 1844 by the infamous warrior Chief Tzouhalem, whose favourite activity was to bind captives, march them up a hill, and kick them over the cliff. You can visit this location today at Mount Tzouhalem near Duncan, where ironically they erected a large metal cross.   9. BC was so bankrupt from having no gold (ironically) that they joined Canada in 1871 (4 years after Canada "confederated")  10. The province, British Columbia, is called that because it is (or was) the "British" side of the Columbia River (well until the Americans altered the deal).    If you are interested for more information, hmu on my insta! wildmanhistory :D

No mention of the Battle of new Orleans. Guess you read the cliff notes right.  So this video would be the cliff notes of the cliff notes?  The Battle of New Orleans, even though it happened after the treaty was signed, was the most important battle for the US in the war of 1812.  The British were not only wanting to take New Orleans but to take control of the Mississippi and thus restricting any further expansion of the US westward.

OK an ironic fact I just found out while looking at the Wikipedia of George Pickett. After the Civil War he feared prosecution because he was a major general for the confederate army. In order to escape prosecution he ran away to... Canada. He hid out in Canada in order to prevent himself from being arrested. Ulysses S. Grant interceded on his behalf though and he was allowed to return to the United States and live out the rest of his life back home in Virginia.

26:30 Battles drawing crowds of civilian spectators was not unheard of, especially in cases when tensions had long been brewing and word had had a chance to spread. This all changed very suddenly one day in the early civil war when at the First Battle of Bull Run, a merry company of picnicers having hunkered down on a hill overlooking the battlefield suddenly got heavily shelled by mistake. From that point on civilians was discouraged to spectate military clashes - for their own sake, and not without some grumbling from commanding officers on both sides over losing what they thought of encouraging cheering, good for morale and displays of heroism among the soldiers. Fun fact that Oversimplified didn't bring up: you see that little blue bit east of Vancouver Island at 9:22? That's Point Roberts, Washington, which has a population of about 1,300 and was ignored by that treaty, so though it would have been easier for everyone involved for that to be Canada, it's part of America, and kids in fourth grade and beyond have to cross an international border twice, with a 40-minute drive through BC, to go to school in Blaine, WA.

Fun Fact: Thereâ€™s Wild Gazelles that live up in the San Juan Islands. Yep, AFRICAN Gazelles.  Why? Because the islands used to be a hotspot for Rich American â€œGentlemenâ€ and they transported African wildlife to the islands to use them for sport hunting. For now, they populate one of the northern islands and it is illegal to set foot on that particular island. You can see the herds by boats or from neighboring islands. The island is called Spieden Island.

English Camp was green and prestine, though the condition of American Camp could have changed in 19 years. Nice place, I'd advise people visit it! Couldn't say it was much like the American main land

2:40 I like oversimplified but the war in 1812 is taught as a British victory in both Canada and Britain due to the fact that Britain successfully defended its territories from an USA attack and the USA sued for peace when Britain threatened to send in its actually army. The only reason as to why Britain didn't annex the USA after this war was because Britain was currently tangled up in the Napoleonic Wars. This means that they could not afford to maintain the cost of owning the USA and because annexing the USA would lead to further war with Europe since the main reason for the Napoleonic wars was Frenchs annexing of land which was used as a excuse by the European powers to declare war. This means that Britain couldn't annex the USA since it was far to risky.

Let me tell you of a story of a San Juan pig. It wasn't worth much cause it wasn't very big, But it rooted in a garden and it nearly caused a fray, Between the King of England and the U. S. A.   Now the Pig it was Canadian, the settler was a Yank What the pig did to his garden was more than just a prank, For it dug up his potatoes and it tore down his fence, Since it wasn't just the first time Cutler's anger was immense.   When he saw the pig a-rootin', Lyman Cutter, he got sore. He grabbed up his musket, for the pig he tore. The pig saw him comin' and headed for the woods, But he stopped at the edge, and Cutler shot him good.   Then Cutler felt regretful and went down to Hudson's Bay, And told the clerk in charge of the porker he would pay. Griffin said, "One hundred dollars, he's a prize breeding boar." Cutler told him "I'll pay three, and not a penny more."   Then up stepped A. G. Dallas, and said, "See here, my man, You're already trespassing upon Canadian land. You know it's British country from Rosario to the west," "Not so," said Lyman Cutler, "East of Haro is U. S."   Well, the settlers they backed Cutler with their muskets in their hands. The British thought it wiser not to make a stand. The stars and stripes were hoisted to celebrate the day, And were seen by General Hamey a-sail in' on the bay.   The general came ashore and he listened to their tale. He was a man of action and to help he did not fail. To Fort Bellingham he sent 'ere he sailed away again, And down came Captain Pickett with a company of men.   Then up sailed the British with war ships one, two, three, Which made a few too many for Pickett's company. They had to find a way to even up the score, So he sent to Fort Steilacoom and got five hundred more.   Well they argued in the Senate, and in the House of Lords, And they didn't make much progress but they used a lot of words. So they asked the German Emperor the boundary to define, And tell those treaty makers where to draw the line.   Now the Kaiser gave his answer in 1872, And said that Haro Strait was where the line went through. Well they called it a war, but it wasn't very big And the only one got killed was a little British pig.

#3 trending let's go! Edit: Now it is #1!
What is with naval officers averting wars due to miscommunication? It has some weird parallels to the Soviet officer Vasili Arkhipov.   If you didn't know, during the Cuban Missile Crisis, US naval forces attempted to intercept a Soviet submarine in international waters. They dropped "signalling depth charges" (basically, firing warning shots) to try and tell the submarine to surface. The submarine interpreted this as an attack, and thought WW3 had broken out. They couldn't use their radio while submerged, nor could they communicate with the other nearby submarines, so the two officers on board decided to launch their nuclear missile. Vasili voted no, however, and a launch required a unanimous vote.   The absolutely crazy part of it is that Vasili was just onboard as a fluke. He was in charge of the entire submarine floatilla, so he was also second in command of that specific submarine (yes, he was both the captain's superior, AND subordinate). None of the other submarines had a 3rd officer, just the captain and political officer (who both said yes on Vasili's sub). This is how close we came to nuclear armageddon. It was nothing but sheer luck that Vasili happened to be in the right place, at the right time, to avert disaster on an unimaginable scale.

Also love the videos, but this one glossed over major historical points just to paint America's and white people in a bad light, and that's kinda odd.  American expansion didn't happen because no white people lived to the west, it was because natives were different tribes who had wars with each other and wars with the Americans.   Natives tended to not settle in one spot and raided settlements, Americans retaliated and then Natives retaliated.  It wasn't a genocide but wars.  Wars that turned barbaric at times from both sides.

The Pig War was a confrontation in 1859 between the United States and the United Kingdom over the Britishâ€“U.S. border in the San Juan Islands, between Vancouver Island (present-day Canada) and the State of Washington. The Pig War, so called because it was triggered by the shooting of a pig, is also called the Pig Episode, the Pig and Potato War, the San Juan Boundary Dispute and the Northwestern Boundary Dispute. Despite being referred to as a war, there were no casualties on either side.

Ok so hear me out... I have thought long and hard about this. What if we convinced the Quebecois to declare independence. In the chaos, America would be a great alternative. Even if we don't take the whole thing... We can still get a little nibble. Think of all the oil in Alberta... We could suck the ground dry and unify there dairy laws to improve the quality of life for everyone in north America except for the Quebecois and the Mexicans, but they don't speak English so that's not a huge loss.
Honestly... A confederation of north American states would be cool.  Autonomous nations/states United under a singular joint economic sphere to rival the rising alliances in Europe and Asia.   Could call it The North American Union, or confederation of North American states.  We are the "new" lands of the world and share a common story of colonial powers overruling us before we gained our independency from those colonial powers.  Besides. With the economic potential of Canada, Mexico, and the United States- jobs could remain in North America and a sense of autarky be instilled.  We would be able to in times of need unify military force from every nation in the confederation and form a defensive line from coast to coast.  Politically of course it could be more independent to localities in terms of each nation.  America it's president Canada it's PM, and likewise across all members- but a joint congress on matters of the supernation could be formed and address important things concerning the economy and military/emergening issues.  Things on the social level would remain in the hands of local administration.  (Honestly though as a constitutionalist with libertarian views I feel that on a social scale freedom for all- barring the consequences of crimes of society of course.  This has been a long one.  But I may draft something later about this.  I know other people have theorized this but I feel that should it ever be achieved, North America as a whole would be able to prosper and thrive for years to come.

there is 1 reason the US doesn't take over canada... cost. Canada benefits too much from the US to even dare talk war and the massive cost of footing the bill for not only the war, but also federalizing the resources we already receive, including their population into our federal aid programs, and reorganizing their territories into states for proper voting is just not worth the effort. They are basically like our friendly neighbors who we have little to no political discourse with... though we are still trying to get them to drill through 300ft of permafrost and frozen earth to access some of the largest untapped crude oil in the world.  Mexico and the central americas are more likely targets if we were serious into expansion. The main target would be gaining full control over the panama canal, but the cheep labor, expanded sea boards with reduced land borders, and additional rare earths are all a big plus. Our eastern coast has a massive population, but pacific shipping lanes have to wait up to a month and pay thousands just to use the canal that WE built, putting additional stress on our highway and railing infrastructure. (Covid brought this weakness to light) Though central america may seem poor, it's because it is primarily controlled by dictators and drug traffickers; a bit of americanization can quickly turn it into an industrial zone that would completely break our reliance on foreign countries.  PS: I DO NOT PROMOTE WAR WITH MEXICO x.x China and our 30 trillion dollar debt needs to get its ass kicked before we think of something like that

Fun little comment on the ending there from a Canadian....  You yanks actually have a sizable maple syrup industry, and ironically from what I have heard quite a bit of American maple syrup is of superior quality (as much as that pains me to say). The Canadian maple syrup industry, though larger is run by a cartel filled with control freaks. The American maple syrup industry does not have that problem, and with fewer ideal sugar bushes has had to get creative and has made several notable innovations in the industry.

Fun Fact! After the Civil War, President Andrew Johnson appointed Gen. Harney to the Indian Peace Commission, which he served on from between 1865 and 1868. There, he sought to prevent violations of existing peace treaties with the Native Americans, and he (allegedly) became known as â€œMan-Who-Keeps-His-Wordâ€ by the Sioux. However, he was also dubbed â€œWoman Killerâ€ by those same tribes in reference to the time troops under his command massacred a Sioux village in 1855, with the vast majority of victims being women and children.   Basically, this guy was Manifest Destiny personified.

A lot of channels with an irregular upload schedule and large following end up having a lot of hype surrounding new video uploads and because of this, one mistake can end it all. A single bad or boring video can end a channel for good in the eyes of most people. Because of this, I get nervous every time an OverSimplified video drops; the hype is usually built up naturally as the fanbase realizes that its been several months since the last video, and when it finally hits, I'm worried it might not stand up to the hype built. With this video, I finally concede. OverSimplified has grown from a small, basic channel describing historical battles and wars, with interspersed jokes throughout, to a major player in the Educational YouTube genre. I am no longer worried about potential flops. The time and energy devoted to these videos shows on many many levels. The new animation details, increased video length, and overall growth of this channel has put some major studios to shame. I hope to watch these videos for many, MANY, years into the future.

37:08 maybe, they could have gone to war. I think I remember hearing a nasty incident in the UN Korean demilitarized zone called operation Paul Bunyan. It was that North Korean troops kept kidnapped South Korean and American troops in the DMZ. This was a problem and there was also a tree on the border line which was blocking the view, so to better see the one spot of the zone, the South Koreans and Americans tried to cut down the tree. When they saw this, a fight broke out between the two sides, but never blew up into another full scale conflict. So if fighting did break out, it would be localized to the island and both sides would probably have been court marshaled.  Edit: the mention of operation Paul Bunyan was because a war like that would be localized to that island and would be similar to what happened in DMZ as in there would mostly border skirmishes.

Dear Oversimplified, please stick to the history first and foremost!  Don't get me wrong, I LOVE your content, but today's history lesson felt very different from what we are used to, especially the crazy outro!! I feel like this video was full of extra scenes and gags that took away from the learning experience. The video was very long despite this being a short story that could have been condensed into a mini-war. I think the lack or historical subject matter, mixed with your desire to make a full length video added some unwelcome changes to your storytelling! Given your channel's status, we want to see more central history videos such as the Vietnam War, the War of 1812, or the English Civil War. Your old style was perfect! With your next release, please grace us with the likes of your masterpieces, such as Napoleonic Wars, Prohibition, and the Russian Revolution; sticking to the history while not refraining to add the necessary fun we've all fallen in love with!! Thanks for hearing us out!

You left out that the US had a significant bolster to their claim - A old Spanish spoon was found on San Juan Island and the US argued that it had acquired Spanish territory and that included those islands.   It was first in time basis claim and Spain was there first and USA piggy backed their claim that evidence.  (sorry could not help the pun).  A similar claim was done for the US claim on the Oregon Territory when in 1792 Captain Gray of the US Columbia was the first person to sail down the river and walk along its banks.  He got there before Captain Vancouver who tried to beat him there unknowing that Gray had already been there.   Spain and Britain almost went to world over the Pacific Northwest in 1790s and it was resolved by the Nootka Sound Convention.

i am not gonna lie although Canada's healthcare looks good on paper the long wait times to get said treatments have left many people dead. If you want even a simple mri which in the u.s you can get in a week and pay a proportional amount depending on insurance plan can be life saving. This is why in New York as an example we have many Canadians travel over the border for medical treatment although it is obviously the wealthier Canadians with the costs of passports and transportation.  And to even poke more fun at the northern neighbors their law has it where someone who is biologically male can sue for not getting a Brazilian wax job meant for females due to lets say for certain people in the comment sections delicate body parts and win as a precedent. On one hand yes people can identify as whatever they want but when it comes to procedures that can do harm it was either you get sued if you do or sued if you don't.  If any and all criticism of modern United States can be made that would easily be a 50 paged single space essay with 12 point font on Microsoft word, but my biggest gripe at least within my countries own borders is our taxation and overspending. If taxes for middle and lower income families were reduced federally better insurance would naturally be more affordable, and with a reallocation of how we spend our money in government as a you need to spend your whole budget this fiscal year or else it is cut is screwy too as if anything if they have a remaining budget the smart thing to do would be to give a smaller budget that equates to what they initially got subtracted from what was left over.
